nodes.text: Reporting both the ensemble-average (GDP per capita) growth rate and the time-average (DDP per capita) growth rate, together with their difference (ergodicity gap), provides a more complete and policy-relevant picture of national economic performance than reporting GDP per capita growth alone

Under random multiplicative income dynamics the ensemble-average growth rate (growth of mean income, identified with GDP per capita growth) is conceptually distinct from the time-average growth rate (long-run growth experienced by an individual, identified with DDP per capita growth)

Mathematically, for multiplicative growth the ergodicity transformation is the logarithm, so individual growth rates are g_i = delta ln x_i / delta t, which are ergodic while raw additive income changes are not
Jensen's inequality implies the ensemble-average growth rate exceeds or equals the time-average growth rate (ensemble minus time is non-negative), with equality only under perfect equality of incomes

We analyze random multiplicative growth models (including geometric Brownian motion) analytically and estimate growth measures empirically for the United States and France using World Inequality Database quantile data and percentile approximations to compute geometric means and averages

In geometric Brownian motion (GBM) with drift mu and volatility sigma: ensemble-average growth rate g_ensemble = mu, time-average growth rate g_time = mu minus sigma squared over two, and ergodicity gap growth rate dJ/dt = sigma squared over two (so J(t) = sigma squared t over two up to constant)

The time-average growth rate (DDP per capita) can be computed from cross-sectional initial and terminal distributions as the change in the mean log income, so it is independent of individual rank mobility and does not require panel data

Empirical finding: in the United States since about 1980 GDP per capita (ensemble growth) grew substantially faster than DDP per capita (time-average growth), while in France the two growth rates remained much closer over the past fifty years

Conclusion: because ensemble-average growth can systematically overestimate typical individual experience when incomes evolve multiplicatively, statistical agencies should compile and report ensemble-average growth, time-average growth (DDP per capita), and their difference (ergodicity gap / MLD)

Claim: persistent divergence where GDP per capita grows faster than DDP per capita can create a political disconnect between policymakers focused on aggregate growth and citizens experiencing lower typical long-run growth

Method detail: estimating the time-average growth rate from quantile data uses the geometric mean (exp of mean log income) approximated by averaging percentile mean incomes; bounds from quantile endpoints show the percentile-based estimate is robust

Limitation: DDP per capita (geometric mean) is sensitive to low-income measurement, so the authors truncate or test sensitivity (e.g., excluding bottom decile) and show qualitative conclusions are robust to reasonable truncation choices

Assumption: random multiplicative growth is a null model capturing proportional proportional fluctuations (Gibrat's law), stationarity of multipliers, and independence over time; deviations from the model (reallocation, correlations) may alter quantitative implications

Context: ergodicity economics frames differences between ensemble and time averages as central; prior literature links GDP per capita to plutocratic measures and geometric mean to people-weighted or democratic measures
